Award.AwardTitle: Refining the Purine/Histidine/Thiamine Biosynthetic pathways in Salmonella enterica as a model network

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
A question that spans biology is how metabolic pathways combine to generate the robust and efficient physiology of a living cell. In this project, investigators will probe the physiology of a cell by treating the cell as a complex system, and using tools that include generation of mathematical models of the metabolic system in question, testing of these models with genetic/biochemical analysis, and quantify the metabolites that make up the system. Together, results from each of these areas will inform the other and provide new understanding of the complex interplay of metabolic pathways that lead to the robustness of living systems. Student and postdoctoral personnel involved in this project will be trained at the interface of biology, chemistry, biotechnology, mathematics, and computation. Thus in addition to scientific insights, the work proposed will contribute to the development of critically needed human resources. The PI is further committed to human resource development with a strategy to increase the participation of Puerto Rican students in the research enterprise at the University of Georgia.

The proposed work is a collaboration between a microbial physiologist and and a systems biologist with expertise in metabolic modeling; and an expert in metabolomics and synthetic chemistry. This interdisciplinary project builds the initial collaboration to address a common question: How should one optimally represent the metabolic network of a cell in a succinct, quantitative way that is reliable and predictive, and that can be experimentally confirmed? The specific experimental system is are the purine/histidine/thiamine biosynthetic pathways, which are amenable to precise manipulations and can be used to test a wide array of predictions generated by metabolomic and modeling approaches. This feature of the project will allow the team to establish a "proof of principle" that it is possible to capture all pertinent features of a metabolic system with sufficient granularity to claim that the system is "understood". A convincing proof of this nature has not been provided thus far, but is critically needed in the field of metabolomics. From the modeling perspective, the chosen bacterial system provides a means to generate extensive data from a single system that can be used to refine and train a sequence of models in ways that are not possible with large-scale networks, which depend on data from diverse sources and are intrinsically of variable quality. This multidisciplinary approach will generate new knowledge and advance the approaches needed to quantitatively measure and model metabolism from sets of experimental data. It will also advance the development of tools and techniques that are transferrable to studies of metabolism in all kingdoms of life.

POR.DRECONTENT:
All living systems are made up of a complex network of biochemical pathways, collectively termed metabolism. It is the interactions between these pathways that allow an organism to adapt and respond to different situations and environments. A central question in biology is how the components of metabolism work together to accomplish the capabilities we associate with living cells and organisms. Historically these questions have been addressed by investigators in distinct disciplines, each of which had its own unique strengths, but also limitations.  This proposal included three established investigators with distinct expertise in computational, experimental and technical approaches to biology. Specifically, we initiated a study that was meant to confirm the ability to integrate these approaches toward a better understanding of metabolism, and chose to work with a bacterial system. Microbes (e.g., bacteria) are the simplest organisms to study and have the broadest number of tools available for this work. Importantly, metabolic strategies are frequently conserved across biology, and so our results can often be extrapolated to define general biological paradigms. The large body of knowledge about the integration of metabolic pathways for thiamine, purine and histidine biosynthesis obtained by classical experimental methods, provided a case study for the integration of modern computational, technological, and experimental tools. The combination of the three disciplines used here is critical for the future of metabolic studies and will provide an unparalleled level of understanding of the inner working of the cell. We confirmed that collectively these tools could provide scientific insights not generated by a single approach. Equally importantly, we identified caveats, and areas of this multidisciplinary approach that need to be refined moving forward. Our work emphasized the need to continually assess and develop new tools and to validate results and predictions with experimental approaches as emerging technologies are expanded and refined. The long-term goal of this work is to contribute to a dynamic map of the regulated flow of metabolites through the pathway that make up metabolism, much like a traffic map that responds to traffic jams. A significant outcome of this project was the training of young scientists. Each of the personnel involved in this project was exposed to and trained in interdisciplinary science. This training is increasingly critical in the future since interdisciplinary science requires continual innovation by unforeseeable combinations of the various technical and computational sectors of society.
